Let $A\subseteq \mathbb{N}$ be a set such that $\lvert A\cap \{1,\ldots,N\}\rvert \gg \log N$ for all large $N$. Let $f(n)$ count the number of solutions to $n=p+a$ for $p$ prime and $a\in A$. Is it true that $\limsup f(n)=\infty$?



Erd\H{o}s \cite{Er50} proved this when $A=\{2^k : k\geq 0\}$.

The answer is yes, as proved by Chen and Ding \cite{ChDi22} - in fact, the assumption that $\lvert A\cap \{1,\ldots,N\}\rvert \gg \log N$ can be replaced just with the assumption that $A$ is infinite.

See also [236].




References


[ChDi22] Chen, Y.-G. and Ding, Y., On a conjecture of Erd\H{o}s. arXiv:2201.10727 (2022).

[Er50] Erd\"{o}s, P., On integers of the form $2^k+p$ and some related problems. Summa Brasil. Math. (1950), 113-123.
